name: Golden Suisse
content: Golden Suisse operates similarly to traditional Swiss gold banks of the 19th century. Client deposits and investments are physical gold bars and bullion currencies.Our award-winning banking patented technology allows our clients to utilize their own personal gold  stored in Switzerland to make payments, transfers, and credit card purchases from any location across the globe.As a result, we are more secure than any private bank in the world, including by standards set out by the Bank of International Settlement, and  furthermore as we deal with gold we are also free from inflation risks.

name: Mauricio Mora Caballero
content: La facilidad con que las herramientas analÃ­ticas permiten que cada vez mÃ¡s personas ejecuten procedimientos es impresionanteğŸ‘ğŸ‘Reduciendo la brecha de conocimiento y facilitando la implementaciÃ³n de cualquier tipo de modeloğŸ‘ğŸ‘Sin embargo, existen procedimientos estadÃ­sticos (regresiÃ³n lineal, regresiÃ³n logÃ­stica binaria, mÃºltiple, anÃ¡lisis discriminante...) que necesitan ğŸ‘€validar supuestos para que sea correcto su usoğŸ‘€Si no se cumplen estos supuestos, tenemos una ecuaciÃ³n muy linda que no tiene fundamento matemÃ¡tico y no puede usarseğŸ˜­. Es importante que sepamos cuales son y cÃ³mo se deben probar, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de ejecutar el modelo y usarloğŸ˜ƒEn las regresiones lineales, se debe validar antes de ejecutar el modelo:1. La cantidad de variables que se usen como independientes no puede ser mÃ¡s que la cantidad de registros2. Las variables independientes no deben estar correlacionadas entre sÃ­ (ausencia de Multicolinealidad)3. Los errores son idd (independientes e idÃ©nticamente distribuidos) con distribuciÃ³n normal con media cero y varianza constante.En siguientes publicaciones quiero ğŸ”indagarğŸ” un poco mÃ¡s en cÃ³mo se deben validar los supuestos de los modelos estadÃ­sticosDar sugerencia de modelos (variaciones) que pueden tener el mismo alcance cuando no se cumplen los supuestosğŸ‘ğŸ‘.Por ejemplo, al tener variables independientes correlacionadosâ•â• se desarrollaron estrategias de regularizaciÃ³n, creando variaciones de la regresiÃ³n lineal conocidas como Lasso, Ridge o Elastic Net. En tu caso, estas probando los supuestos de las regresiones linealesâ”â” lo estÃ¡s haciendo de forma correctaâ”â”Si quieres saber mÃ¡s de estos temas, no dudes en escribirmeâ•â•#analÃ­ticaÂ #analisisdedatosÂ #regresionÂ #regresionlinealÂ #supuestosÂ #lassoÂ #ridgeÂ #elasticnetÂ #errorÂ #estadisticaÂ #modelos

name: Carlos L. Guardiola OrtuÃ±o
content: Â¿Alguna vez te has preguntadoâ€¦ğŸ”¬ â€¦ hasta quÃ© punto es real que podamos alterar las capacidades del ser humano a travÃ©s de la tecnologÃ­a? Entonces, Â¿cuÃ¡l es el papel de la tecnologÃ­a y quiÃ©n tiene que tomar las decisiones?ğŸ’ Si los avances de la tecnologÃ­a son intencionales y por tanto estÃ¡n dirigidos Â¿significa el transhumanismo que seremos la primera especie que va a evolucionar por diseÃ±o?â›“ Â¿CÃ³mo van a coexistir las diferentes especies de humanos y transhumanos en el mismo lugar y al mismo tiempo? Â¿Estaremos creando una nueva forma de desigualdad? Â¿De discriminaciÃ³n? Â¿De esclavitud?ğŸŒ Â¿Y quÃ© pasa con la Tierra? Â¿QuÃ© recursos tenemos que explotar para construir el siguiente estado evolutivo del ser humano, y quÃ© recursos vamos a tener que consumir para mantenerlo? Â¿Es la colonizaciÃ³n del espacio la respuesta? âš° Â¿En quÃ© momento vamos a alcanzar la inmortalidad? Â¿Debemos alcanzarla? Hace mÃ¡s de 4.000 aÃ±os se escribiÃ³ el viaje de Gilgamesh en busca de la inmortalidad. Hoy, cientÃ­ficos como Ray Kurzweil predicen que el ser humano lograrÃ¡ la inmortalidad en el aÃ±o 2030..Huxley acuÃ±Ã³ el concepto de "transhumanismo" para reflejar la idea de que la humanidad debÃ­a usar la ciencia y la tecnologÃ­a para mejorar las capacidades y superar nuestras limitaciones biolÃ³gicas.More va mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de la visiÃ³n del transhumanismo como continuaciÃ³n natural del proceso de evoluciÃ³n, considera que el ser humano tiene la capacidad y la responsabilidad de mejorar su propia naturaleza biolÃ³gica y mental.Otros como Bostrom son partidarios de la idea del "mejoramiento moral", que propone que la tecnologÃ­a puede ser utilizada para mejorar las capacidades morales y Ã©ticas de los seres humanos.Y por Ãºltimo, Clark considera que desde hace dÃ©cadas el ser humano han utilizado la tecnologÃ­a para reemplazar o potenciar sus habilidades fÃ­sicas, y que el reto del transhumanismo es la extensiÃ³n de las capacidades cognitivas del ser humano.El jueves 18 de mayo hablamos de Transhumanismo con Isabel FernÃ¡ndez PeÃ±uelas licenciada en FilosofÃ­a y especialista en LÃ³gica, FilosofÃ­a de la Ciencia e Inteligencia Artificial. DespuÃ©s de una carrera de 30 aÃ±os vinculada a la InnovaciÃ³n en empresas como Atos, FatWire y Oracle, ha fundado The Futures Factory, un estudio de prospectiva estratÃ©gica.En fin. Que mientras no podamos reunirnos telepÃ¡ticamente, tendremos que seguir con aforo reducido, asÃ­ es la vida ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ AquÃ­ las entradas

name: Arnold Ma
content: ğŸ¤‘ Guangdong alone = Mexico's GDP!Will China STILL be a strong economy in 15 years?ğŸ‘‡ China: from a poor struggling nation, to the worldâ€™s economic powerhouse.It all started with the æ”¹é©å¼€æ”¾ (or Reform & Opening up) - the policy that helped turn China into an economic miracle.10% growth rates were maintained for literally decades since the late 70s.In 2022, the 3 fastest growing provinces were Fujian & Jiangxi (4.7%).Nowadays, a single province (sometimes even city!) may *surpass* the GDP of a whole country abroad ğŸ˜³ Switzerland < SichuanÂ Â Sweden < HenanÂ  There are several reasons, but these 3 played a big role: ã€1ã€‘ FocusÂ  Many small cities in China focused on contributing to + rapidly developing very specific industries. This also created new selling points to attract foreign investment. ã€2ã€‘ Scale Chinaâ€™s own massive domestic market size (i.e. vast consumer base) is very self-sufficient + capable of generating significant economic growth. Lifting people out of poverty created a positive feedback loop ğŸ™ ã€3ã€‘Infrastructure By investing in high-speed rail systems, 5G networks, parks, real estate, etc. - the country grew better integrated, further boostingÂ its productivity & growth. ğŸš¨As remarkable as all of that is, itâ€™s not all rainbows and sunshine... There is now a massive wealth inequality gap among income groups + urban/rural divide that was created as a result.Â  This has become the NEXT big challenge to tackle!Â  Do you think China will maintain its economic status? Which country/city will rise up next? ğŸ¤”Arnold Ma #China #economy #growth #business #success

name: Pablo SÃ¡nchez Arias
content: Boost Your R Code's Performance with parSapply ğŸš€Hey LinkedIn fam! ğŸ‘‹ Are you looking to supercharge your R code and make it run faster? ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ Today, I want to share with you an amazing function in R called parSapply that can significantly speed up your computations. ğŸ’¨parSapply is a parallel computing function in R that allows you to distribute computations across multiple cores or processors, harnessing the power of parallel processing. ğŸš€ By using parSapply, you can take advantage of the full processing power of your machine, making your code more efficient and saving you precious time âŒ›.Here's a simple example of how parSapply can be used to speed up your code:```R# Load the parallel packagelibrary(parallel)# Define a function to be applied in parallelmy_function <- function(x) {Â # Perform some computationally intensive taskÂ # ...}# Create a vector of inputsmy_data <- 1:100# Apply the function in parallel using parSapplyresults <- parSapply(my_data, my_function)```In this example, parSapply distributes the computations of the `my_function` across multiple cores, processing each element of `my_data` simultaneously. This can lead to a significant speedup compared to the sequential version of the code.By leveraging parallel processing with parSapply, you can tackle computationally intensive tasks more efficiently, such as large-scale simulations, data processing, or complex calculations. ğŸ’ªSo, if you find yourself working with large datasets or performing repetitive calculations in R, give parSapply a try! It's a powerful tool that can make a noticeable difference in your code's performance. âš¡ï¸If you're interested in learning more about optimizing your R code and unlocking its full potential, I highly recommend checking out DataCamp's course "Writing Efficient R Code" (link: [https://lnkd.in/dVwBqbAN]). It covers various techniques and best practices to improve the efficiency and speed of your R code.Remember, in today's data-driven world, every second counts when it comes to data analysis and processing. Stay ahead of the game by optimizing your R code with parSapply and other performance-enhancing techniques. Happy coding! ğŸ’»âœ¨#RProgramming #DataScience #ParallelProcessing #EfficientCoding #DataCamp

name: Claude Loeffen
content: "Please don't prep the candidates for interviews".Have you ever been told this by a hiring manager? I have.  â—"Over-preparation might make a candidate come across as rehearsed or not authentic"â—â—"If a candidate is not prepared for certain questions or situations, their response can provide insights into their problem-solving skills"â—While I respect their perspective I always highly recommend them to let us prepare candidates for their interviews.But how can you get them on your side? Just telling them that it highly improves the candidate experience is not enough.I see better results when pointing out the effect it could have on the "INTERVIEW-TEAM EXPERIENCE":1ï¸âƒ£ Time Consuming: Unprepared candidates may need to have basic concepts or processes explained to them, which can extend the duration of the interview.2ï¸âƒ£ Increased Frustration: Interviewers may become frustrated if they need to repeatedly clarify questions or concepts due to a candidate's lack of understanding.3ï¸âƒ£ Lack of Engagement: An unprepared candidate is less likely to ask insightful questions or engage in meaningful conversation, resulting in a more monotonous interview experience.4ï¸âƒ£ More Follow-Up Interviews: If a candidate is unprepared, it may necessitate further rounds of interviews, placing additional burdens on the interview team.5ï¸âƒ£ Hindered Decision-Making: The lack of clarity and depth in an unprepared candidate's responses can make the hiring decision more challenging.6ï¸âƒ£  Negative Perception: Continually dealing with unprepared candidates can lead to a negative perception of the recruitment process or the recruitment team involved.In the end, we want more than just to find people for jobs. We want to help skilled people and great companies find each other. We believe that getting candidates ready for interviews is a key step in doing this.In your opinion, what role should recruiters play in preparing candidates for interviews?#candidateexperience #interviewing #interviewpreparation #talentacquisition #hiringmanagers

name: Pablo SÃ¡nchez Arias
content: ğŸ“¢ Boosting Your Data Manipulation Skills in R: The Power of ymd() ğŸš€Are you tired of dealing with messy date formats in your data? Look no further! Let me introduce you to the amazing `ymd()` function in R, which stands for "year-month-day."The `ymd()` function is part of the `lubridate` package, a powerful toolkit for handling dates and times in R. It allows you to effortlessly convert character strings representing dates into proper date objects, making your data manipulation tasks a breeze.Here's a quick example to illustrate the magic of `ymd()`:```Rlibrary(lubridate)# Convert character strings to date objectsdate_strings <- c("2023-05-15", "2023-06-20", "2023-07-10")dates <- ymd(date_strings)# Perform operations with datesearliest_date <- min(dates)latest_date <- max(dates)date_diff <- latest_date - earliest_date# Wow! Manipulating dates has never been easier with ymd()! ğŸ‰```By using `ymd()`, you can directly convert date strings in the "yyyy-mm-dd" format to date objects without worrying about the specific formatting details. It intelligently recognizes the year, month, and day components, allowing you to focus on your analysis rather than spending time on data cleaning.So, whether you're working with time series data, conducting trend analysis, or simply need to extract specific components from dates, `ymd()` will be your new best friend.Ready to level up your data manipulation game in R? Explore the `ymd()` function from the `lubridate` package and unlock the full potential of your date-related tasks! ğŸ“…ğŸ’ª#DataManipulation #RProgramming #DateHandling #lubridate #ymdFunction

name: John Crickett
content: If I were to start my programming journey again, I would learn these three programming languages:1. Python2. TypeScript3. RustIn that order.Hereâ€™s why Python:Python has a comprehensive standard library that makes it easy to do most things with just the language itself. You can also just download the interpreter and go!Python is also easy to learn. Its simple syntax and readability make it an excellent choice for beginners, while still providing experienced programmers with the tools they need to tackle complex problems.Python is one of the most in-demand skills in the job market today. From data engineering and data scientist to software engineers, Python is used across a wide range of industries and applications.So if you're just starting out on your programming journey Python is a great fit.Hereâ€™s why TypeScript:TypeScript combines the benefits of JavaScript (and all of itâ€™s useful ecosystem) with type-checking. This type-checking allows the compiler to catch many potential bugs at compile time rather than runtime.TypeScript is also easy to learn. Its relatively simple syntax and readability make it an excellent choice for junior to intermediate developers moving into their first typed programming language, while still providing the tools you need to tackle complex problems.TypeScript is also one of the most in-demand skills in the job market today - fourth on a recent survey behind Python and JavaScript (which it will probably overtake soon).Hereâ€™s why Rust:Rust straddles the line between application and systems programming language. As such itâ€™s well suited to writing both applications and systems software. Being both a high level language and at the same time offering zero-cost abstractions and built in support for concurrency which allows us to write performant code.Rust has a number of features, i.e. immutable, by default, type safety and ownership that help detect or prevent common programming errors, i.e. memory errors, type errors and data races.Rust has a great and rapidly evolving ecosystem offering a wide range of crates and a great command line tool - cargo - to manage dependencies and builds.How about you?
